dailyFunStuff.title: British veteran raises $30 million for UK's National Health Service
dailyFunStuff.content:
Ben Moore, a 99-year-old British veteran, has raised 16 million pounds ($30 million dollars) for the NHS by walking 100 laps around his garden. Since breaking his hip in an accident he has used a walking frame with wheels. He was inspired by the treatment he received from the NHS after his accident and when he was treated for cancer.

As planned, he has completed the laps before his 100th birthday on April 30. His original target was a very modest 1000 pounds. That aim was quickly blown away when his campaign garnered media attention from around the globe.

Cap Tom Moore's actions should inspire us to think about how we can contribute more to helping others!

citation.name: British veteran Tom Moore, 99, completes 100 laps of garden, raising $30 million for UK's NHS - ABC News

dailyFunStuff.title: Two best friends using pocket money to buy toilet paper for elderly neighbours
dailyFunStuff.content:
Amidst the stock piling, two best friends, Lucy and Addyson, aged 4 and 6, have restored faith in humanity by using their tooth fairy money to purchase toilet paper and tissues to donate to their neighbours.

The idea to do this first came up when Addyson discovered that the supermarket had empty shelves in the toilet paper aisle. She selflessly suggested to her mother to buy toilet paper to help out people in their neighbourhood who may not have had the opportunity to buy it.

The best friends have gone around their neighbourhood handing out the toilet paper and tissues to those in pensioner cottages and those who are too unwell to go out. Their thoughtfulness and generosity has touched the hearts of many, especially the elderly who are very grateful for their actions.

The actions of Lucy and Addyson highlight that it is important to carry out acts of kindness and help those in need, rather than stock piling, which makes it more difficult for those who are vulnerable. Thank you Lucy and Addyson for doing your best to support the people in your neighbourhood!

citation.name: Coronavirus Australia: Best friends use pocket money to buy toilet paper for elderly neighbours - news.com.au

dailyFunStuff.title: Lego Masters
dailyFunStuff.content:
For those of you looking for some good wholesome TV, look no further! Lego Masters is a show where teams compete to create some of the coolest Lego builds you have ever seen!

The show airs on Sundays, Mondays and Tuesdays, and can be watched for free at 9now (link below).

citation.name: Lego Masters is the feelgood TV we need in these frazzled, home-schooling times - The Guardian

dailyFunStuff.title: Yale University's Science of Well-Being' Course is now free on Coursera!
dailyFunStuff.content:
The course is taught by Yale psychology professor Laurie Santos. She will guide you through how people think about their own well-being and teach you to implement that knowledge in your own life.

The course contains 10 weeks of material with about 2-3 hours of readings and videos per week. Since it is online, you could even speed through it over a weekend or two!

Check it out at the link below!

citation.name: Yale Is Offering Its 'Science of Well-Being' Course for Free Online - Mental Floss

dailyFunStuff.title: One World: Together At Home
dailyFunStuff.content:
Yesterday, Lady Gaga and a number of other artists teamed up to deliver a global broadcast to support frontline healthcare workers and the World Health Organization. If you missed it, you can still catch a replay today!

  • Channel 10: 10am-12pm
  • MTV Music Australia/New Zealand, MTV Australia, MTV New Zealand, MTV Dance Australia : 6pm-8pm
  • Sunrise, Weekend Sunrise, The Morning Show, The Daily Edition, 7Plus: 10am-12pm

There is also more to explore at their website below, including a pledge you can take as a Global Citizen to stay home and reduce the spread of the virus!

citation.name: One World: Together At Home - Global Citizen

dailyFunStuff.title: Decreased pollution has greatly improved air quality in some Indian cities.
dailyFunStuff.content:
The picture above depicts the himalayas viewed from the city of Punjab. Some residents have claimed such a sight has not been seen in decades.

Read about how this could offer a new vision for Indian cities, in the article below.

citation.name: The Coronavirus Offers a Radical New Vision for India’s Cities

dailyFunStuff.title: Melbourne’s Pete the Generous
dailyFunStuff.content:
Amidst the unemployment challenges for many individuals, good samaritans like Pete Darmos have been helping out whoever they can. Pete is just like any other business owner who owns a local cafe in Melbourne city, however, he was also affected by COVID-19 and was forced to shut down his business. Despite being shut down, Pete has been giving back to the community by donating money to individuals lining outside Centrelink in Box Hill.

Pete who is now dubbed “Pete the Generous”, withdrew $10 000 and handed $100 to each person standing outside Centrelink, as many have lost their jobs. Many of these individuals were in tears and disbelief that Pete had given them the money, which would help them put food on the table.

It is amazing how Pete, who is suffering hardships himself, is still supporting people who are struggling in the community. He also encourages other Australians to donate, if they are able to, to help those who have been affected by the pandemic. Thank you Pete for your generous actions, it is extremely heartwarming to see that people are selfless and considerate during these difficult times.

citation.name: Melbourne man gives out $10,000 to job seekers in Centrelink queue - news.com.au
Pete the generous hands out $100 bills to Melbourne Centrelink queue - 7 news

dailyFunStuff.title: Community in a pot of curry
dailyFunStuff.content:
Pictured above is Paramdeep Singh, a resident of Canberra that is coordinating a team of Australian Sikhs who have been cooking, packing and delivering 100 meals a day to the doorsteps of fellow Canberrans. A core concept in Sikhism is the practice of the "langar" or a "free kitchen". People are fed at the langar regardless of religion, caste, colour, creed, age, gender or social status, to uphold the principle of equality among all people.

When interviewed by ABC News, they said, "Any person who is not able to cook for themselves, we are trying to provide food." This is just one of a number if heartwarming stories coming out of Canberra. Check out more in the linked article!

citation.name: If coronavirus has you feeling (understandably) down, let these stories from the Canberra community cheer you up - ABC News

dailyFunStuff.title: Adopt a Healthcare Worker
dailyFunStuff.content:
A Facegroup group called "Adopt a Healthcare Worker" is now home to thousands of Australians who have offered to assist frontline health worders.

We think this is a wonderful effort and you should definitely check out the Facebook page (click on the image source)!

citation.name: Adopt A Healthcare Worker: The heartwarming campaign supporting Australia's heroic healthcare workers amid the coronavirus crisis - Now to Love

dailyFunStuff.title: Bendigo Community Unite
dailyFunStuff.content:
When facing a pandemic such as COVID-19, it is essential for medical professionals to have adequate supply of vital defence gear to protect them from the droplets that spread the virus. However, there has been a shortage of gowns, goggles, shields, and gloves, especially in the Bendigo area.

Doctors desperate for supplies have resorted to making their own gowns in order to continue to treat those in critical need.

Luckily, nearly 300 Bendigo locals and small businesses have volunteered to help fund, cut and sew homemade protective gowns for doctors to allow them to continue their life saving efforts.

A massive thank you to these selfless and generous individuals who are doing what they can to help health professionals to continue to treat their patients. You are a great example to how Australians can still unite and contribute to help combat the outbreak during self-isolation at home. Extraordinary work Australia!

If you know how to sew or would like to donate materials please contact gownsfordoctors@gmail.com!

citation.name: The GPs who are sewing their own PPE equipment  - Bendigo Advertiser
